defeat.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: She was a woman who hated to admit defeat.
The socialist party suffered a crushing defeat in the elections.
defeat.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The defeat of the army was followed by the establishment of constitutional government.
defeat.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: The party suffered a defeat in the state elections.
The army inflicted a heavy defeat on the English.
If I left my job, I would be admitting defeat.
It can be very hard to accept defeat.
In May 1945 Germany faced defeat at the hands of the Allies.
The polls were forecasting a heavy defeat for the president.
He quit as prime minister following a crushing defeat in regional elections.
They are still bitter about their humiliating defeat.
The party suffered a disastrous defeat in the 2006 election.
The goalkeeper was blamed for the team’s narrow defeat.
It was their worst general election defeat since 1982.
The president resigned following a series of military defeats.
Arsenal are now out of the competition, following their shock defeat by Torquay Town.
defeat.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to win a victory over someone in a war, competition, game etc
defeat.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: They hoped to defeat the enemy at sea.
We were defeated by 3 goals to 2.
defeat.translation[1].definitions[0].not: In everyday English, people usually say beat rather than defeat when talking about sport, games, or elections:
We were beaten by 3 goals to 2.
defeat.translation[1].definitions[1].def: if something defeats you, you cannot understand it and therefore cannot answer or deal with it
defeat.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: It was the last question on the paper that defeated me.
defeat.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: Don’t let your arms relax as that would defeat the object of the exercise.
